Control Specification: Define, implement, and evaluate processes, procedures, and technical measures that ensure the security of the Training Pipeline. This should include the entire codebase used in data preprocessing, model training, and integration components, in addition to datasets and pre-trained models used, following recognized application security best practices (e.g., OWASP Top 10). Regularly review and update these measures to address new security threats and best practices.

Define, implement, and evaluate processes, procedures, and technical measures for the periodic performance of scanning of model artifacts for vulnerabilities and attacks, at each step of the service lifecycle and at each hand over point.
Define, implement, enforce, and evaluate processes and procedures for documenting, approving, communicating, evaluating, and maintaining model documentation such as Model Cards.
Establish minimum characteristics for Model/System Cards and ensure that all Model/System Cards follow this standardized template.

Control Title: Model Documentation / Model Card Validation Requirements
Control Specification: Define, implement, and evaluate processes, procedures, and technical measures for the periodic validation of the Model Card with the purpose of ensuring Model Card consistency with the Model implementation

Define, implement, and evaluate processes and technical measures to regularly assess adversarial threats specific to each AI model. Prioritize potential attack vectors based on model architecture, data sources, and deployment environments

Control Title: Robustness against Adversarial Attack  / Model Hardening
Control Specification:
Define, implement, and evaluate processes, procedures, and technical
measures for Model Hardening to mitigate relevant adversarial attacks as identified in the Threat Analysis and Adversarial Threat Analysis (see control MDS-06)

Regularly calculate and compare checksums using cryptographic hashes of model checkpoints to detect unauthorized modifications (e.g. Model version pinning). Apply at least annually based on the level of risk, or after any change of hands.
Sign models cryptographically and verify signatures to ensure model provenance and ownership, any time the model changes hands or is loaded from storage.

Define, implement, and evaluate processes, procedures, and technical measures for continuous monitoring of model performance metrics over time to identify sudden shifts or unexpected changes in predictions that could degrade model performance.

Evaluate the need for redundancy in model-serving infrastructure. 
Implement redundancy in AI systems based on this evaluation by deploying multiple models, apps, agents, RAG pipelines, etc, maintaining backups of model serving infrastructure, or implementing a Mixture of Experts architecture.
Establish a process to evaluate risk associated with open weight models. Periodically review these risk factors, and implement a process to monitor and mitigate any determined vulnerabilities.
Adopt secure model formats and processes for AI model serialization where applicable.
Establish a control mechanism to ensure that prompts intended for Large Language Models (LLMs) are constructed server-side, preventing the acceptance of fully-formed prompts directly from users.
